unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: How to Reduce the Margin of Error to $1/5$ of the Original?
question_text:
A one-proportion $z$-interval was constructed. A researcher wants to reduce the margin of error to one-fifth of its original margin of error.
What would she have to do to the sample size?

choices.text: This cannot be answered without the sample size.

solution:
The formula for a one-proportion $z$-interval is:

$$\hat { p } \pm z\sqrt { \dfrac { \hat { p } (1-\hat { p } ) }{ n } }$$

The margin of error is the content after the $\pm $, meaning that it is:

$$z\sqrt { \dfrac { \hat { p } (1-\hat { p } ) }{ n } } $$

What we are interested in in this case is what we would have to do to $n$. In order to reduce the margin of error, we have to make $n$ larger, as it is in the denominator. By process of elimination, we can therefore eliminate Choices 'B' and 'C'.
